reviewText:
Shadowgrounds Survivor is the unmistakable sequel to previous years top down horde mode shooter Shadowgrounds. Unmistakable because if you didn't see the title you'd be hard pressed to tell them apart.

That's not to say Survivor doesn't introduce a few new features, multiple playable characters and a more detailed level progression makes the game a good deal more engaging as you go along. The storyline is as was in the original utterly forgettable and can be easily ignored.

The greatest strength of Shadowgrounds Survivor is once again it's use of atmospheric lightning which does a good job at turning otherwise bland encounters with the alien horde into something a little more suspenseful, lending somewhat from the horror genre.

The problem is also, once again, that this is a genre that has done it all before, the top down shooter horde mode gives you nothing new, nothing you haven't seen a hundred times before. You go from room to room in a linear progression stopping only to pick up the occasional ammo pack in between scripted attacks by the same massive blob of aliens you've already killed in the last ten rooms. Even the boss battles mostly boils down to the same run and gun tactics as the rest of the game making playing the game feel like a grind the more you progress.

All in all as with the original the problem is that Shadowgrounds does nothing to innovate. It adds nothing that you didn't see in the last five games you played int this genre and that makes it a tiresome experience for anyone but the most hardcore fans.

This review is for the game ''Shadowgrounds Survivor''.

There's no connection whatsoever to the original game(Is it staged before the first Shadowgrounds game is it staged after,nobody knows.Plus in the first Shadowgrounds game the aliens were attacking in order to save the humanity from destroying itself.In Shadowgrounds Survivor the aliens are just mindless creatures,just wanting to kill stuff.I'd really like to know why this happened.Maybe in a sequel?I hope so.
Overall a nice experience.I recommend this game but not for the people who want a challenge.
Thank you Frozenbyte Developers for this game :).

Oy, how could developers go from a decent game into...this. First off, if you play this game immedietly turn off the free camera so that it drops it into an isometric third person shooter. This mimics the first game's camera and it improves the playability of the game immensly.

But my biggest gripe comes from changing the flashlight system. In the first game it matteres to manage it since running out of power where it has to recharge in the dark...is bad. However in this game most of the enviroments you don't need a flashlight. This removes the fun and tense moments of entering a dark room, turning on the flashlight, and realising you are in a nest of critters.

Pros:
-Characters play differently
-Graphics are pretty
-Decent Isometric shooter

Cons:
-Need to play the first game for the 'story'
-Camera is awful until you make it 'classic' style
-Characters are flatter then paper
-Flashlight mechanic sucks now
-Sniper makes the game to easy

Get this one on sale, and only in a bundle with the first one. The first one may be an average game, but it was so much better then this outing. Which stinks, since it really could have been so much better.

reviewText:
Shadowgrounds: Survivor is a top-down shooter set in a darkened environment. A game from 2007, its graphics have aged poorly, but not nearly so poorly as its predecessor; still, close-ups on faces look quite terrible. On the whole, it is a great improvement over its predecessor, with superior pacing and voice acting, and it feels less like a low-budget title. Still, it gets repetitive at the end, and unlike the first game, it lacks boss fights. As such, I would generally recommend Alien Swarm, which is free on Steam, over paying for this game.

Story

A base on Ganymede has been attacked by a horde of aliens. Three survivors work together to save the world:
A soldier, who is the last member of his platoon and is trying to work his way back to the colony.
An old Russian janitor, who seems to enjoy setting things on fire.
A sniper, who keeps a count of every kill she gets.
They are assisted by a scientist, saved early on in the soldier‚Äôs sections, who helps them set up the defense of the colony.
The game‚Äôs story is very bare-bones and exists to serve the gameplay, and in that role, it is adequate; the voice acting is fine and not phoned-in, unlike the first game, and on the whole it serves its purpose, though why the aliens are there is never clarified ‚Äì though on the other hand, maybe it doesn‚Äôt matter.

Gameplay

The game is a top-down shooter. Each character has three weapons plus grenades, and each character has a special power that only they can activate. As you kill aliens, you find upgrades for your weapons, which makes them more powerful and gives them alternate fire mechanisms, and gain experience, which allows you to directly upgrade your characters‚Äô abilities and stats.
On the whole, the gameplay is reasonably engaging, and by switching between different characters with different weapon sets, the game keeps its gameplay somewhat fresh. Unfortunately, by about halfway through the game you have encountered every type of alien present in the game, and as a result the second half of the game is mostly greater and greater numbers of aliens, with the odd ‚Äúdefend the area‚Äù or ‚Äúride around in a mech shooting things‚Äù or ‚Äúsit in a turret shooting things‚Äù thrown in. As a result, the game does wear a bit thin by the end, though the game on the whole isn‚Äôt terribly long.
There is a secret hidden in each level, a S lying around on the ground, which adds a minor exploration aspect to the game, but on the whole, I didn‚Äôt really feel driven to find the things. Still, it was nice that there weren‚Äôt an excessive number of collectables.

Graphics

The game was made in 2007, and while it looks okay when you are looking from the third-person, well-above-the-character perspective, whenever the characters speak their faces are shown on-screen and look absolutely terrible. On the whole, the graphics are serviceable, but it has not aged well and nothing looks really spectacular.

Final Summary

The game is a competent third-person shooter, and you could do worse. However, Alien Swarm is still probably a better game, and it is free on Steam.

reviewText:
I didn't think I liked isometric shooters - then I played the orignial Shadowgrounds.  The controls took a brief getting-used-to, and once I had, I was roll-flipping-behind-the-back shotgunning aliens in 360 degrees.  So fun.

[EDIT] Below is no longer relevant - since I last payed ages ago, the devs have added a setup utility to scale graphics (and more importantly physics) detail - blast away!  I now recommend this game.

This sequel introduced physics objects - which I think is actually a very bad idea, as they briefly slow down the flow of time in the game on older computers.  Part of what makes this original Shadowgrounds so great is it's silky-smooth and consistent gameplay throughout.  Nothing drives me nuts more than inconsistent flow-of-time / speed-of-time in a game.  (I'm looking at YOU, EA.) I'd like to preface this by saying that I haven't played the original Shadowgrounds game yet.

Shadowgrounds Survivor is a very curious mix of top-down shooters and RPGs. On the one hand, it has all the elements for a really good shooter, and also manages to meld them with some RPG elements on the side to keep things interesting.

The soundtrack is top-notch surprisingly, It really does help sell the atmosphere and knows how to transition from that feeling to pure hectic fun when it wants to. The gun effects all sounds really quite effective and powerful. My only gripe is with the creatures' effects, they are all pretty lacking in a way and really failed to get me excited about my fights with them whenever there were no jumpscares to be had. Voice acting isn't too bad and works well for the most part aside from some cringeworthy situations.


A lengthy campaign is a gift that keeps on giving, except when the story is absolutely horrible in writing, and pacing. Could've gone better with some changes to the script and the game's pacing, but I hear the original title is a lot better in that regard.

reviewText:
Shadowgrounds: Survivor is a sidequel [Isn‚Äôt that what you call a game that takes place at the same time as the original, but from a different character‚Äôs perspective?] to Shadowgrounds, and it improves on its predecessor in a number of ways.  Let‚Äôs see how it does it.

First off, the gameplay is almost exactly the same.  Shoot aliens, collect upgrade parts, get new weapons, repeat.  The twist this time, though, is the addition of RPG elements for your 3 distinct characters.  The Marine, Exterminator, and Sniper all have their own set of specialized weapons, and they play completely differently.  You can also upgrade their specific abilities, giving them area control powers or instant kill moves.  This little bit of variation gives a huge boost to this game over the original.

But that is hardly all the improvements that were made.  The graphics are noticably improved as well.  The detail is much sharper, and there are a lot more interactive objects.  Frozenbyte did a great job making the levels this time around, as they all are relatively easy to nagivate, rather than the directionless mazes from the last game. I have mixed feelings about this game. Reading the description I was expecting a full sequel, but this is an expansion pack at best. It adds very little to the original formula, and misses a chance to fix some issues and bring the series to a higher level:

PROS:
- Three different characters, with different weapons and different skill sets.
- Simple RPG style upgradable character skills.
- Better voice acting.
- Enhanced physics using NVIDIA Physx; everything can be moved around and destroyed, updated enemy gibbing.
- Slightly more detailed environments, fog, better particle effects.
- Secrets unlock new gameplay options.
- More varied environments; snowy landscapes, rainy canyon, lava cave, sewers...
- Survival mode.
- The mech.

CONS:
- The campaign can be finished in 4-5 hours, which is half of the time it took me to finish the original. Just when I upgraded all my characters the game was already over.
- Maps are tiny compared to the original game, and are much more linear.
- There are no side missions like in the original, you basically just have to survive from start to end of the level.
- The stories of the three characters have no touching points. Even when they finally meet, you have to just pick one of them to continue. It would be much more interesting if they interracted more during the story, or if you could play with all of them at the same time like in RPG games or like they did it in The Thing.
- There is only one new type of enemy.
- The AI isn't fixed, and enemies still sometimes get stuck, I feel sorry for them :(

Btw, some reviews here mention problems running the game on Windows 7 64bit, but I had no problems.

At the end I had fun playing this expansion"
